@squeezetaxes @TheNFTCPA @defidefenselaw Easier/less expensive
@TheNFTCPA @defidefenselaw Unlikely this case will create a nationwide precedent IMO. They should have taken the case to US Tax Court if that was the desired outcome.
In short: Don't stop reporting your staking rewards as income yet! Sorry to be the bearer of bad news. (4/4)

They requested a refund of a little over $3,000. We don't know what happened in the confidential settlement process, but it's very possible the IRS decided to pony up $3K rather than risk more expensive litigation. (3/4)

This couple sued the IRS for a refund, as anyone can do. But they did so in a District Court of TN; any legal decision from this case would only create precedent in that district. To get a binding legal precedent nationwide, they should have taken it to US Tax Court. (2/4)

Does this mean staking income is non-taxable until sold? Not really... (1/4)
https://t.co/u5mKErT2dt

Did you get a tax form from https://t.co/hP6x0wdVUq? Chances are the numbers are way off! Form 1099-MISC only reports certain types of miscellaneous income, NOT your capital gains. https://t.co/K0Qj4VDW2n

@ape2616 If it's ordinary and necessary, it's generally a deductible expense!
Gas fees for transferring between wallets/exchanges (for personal use): Probably not deductible
NFT artists: Gas fees incurred for business purposes may be deductible

There's no IRS guidance on gas fees. Our general interpretation (NOT legal or tax advice; ask a pro for your specific situation):
1. For purchases, gas can be added to cost basis
2. For sales, gas can be subtracted from sales proceeds https://t.co/2SMgvgVpvZ

@flypueo @TheNFTCPA @thenftattorney Fair market value in USD (at time of claiming) is what you have to report. If you don't claim tokens, there's no tax event.

@flypueo @TheNFTCPA @thenftattorney You have to successfully list an NFT on LooksRare exchange in order to claim the tokens. (Claiming = having "dominion & control" in legal terms.) You have ordinary income at the time you get dominion & control.

@boironattorney @cathsimard_ The recipient inherits the cost basis & acquisition date of the asset; that's why it doesn't count as a "sale" with capital gains implications.

@boironattorney @cathsimard_ You're right that annual & lifetime limits apply. Currently, the annual exclusion is $15K per recipient. When under the annual limit, it doesn't count toward the lifetime limit. There are other nuances to consider so always DYOR or use a pro!
